text: animal health specialist Kerry mower of
the State Department of Game and Fish
takes a call forty elk found dead on her
ranch north east of Santa Fe
I grabbed some equipment put in my
pickup truck and I began to drive and I
got there it was way more than 40 dead
elk
I was dismayed and shocked and alarmed
to find so many carcasses laying out in
the open carry counts a hundred and
thirteen dead elk something bad had
happened and it had happened real fast
one possibility is episodic hemorrhagic
disease or EHD a deadly virus
untreatable in the wild it's spread by
biting insects in 2012 the state of
Nebraska loses over a hundred thousand
white-tailed deer to EHD here the cell
walls rupture from the virus and when
you look at a deer after it's dead and
kind of open you'll see rupturing of the
lungs and many of the major organs to
see if EHD is to blame Kerry must
examine the elk and look for signs of
internal bleeding with over seventy
thousand elk in New Mexico every one of
them is at risk
I began to take samples and I looked at
liver I looked at explain I looked at
lungs and I looked at their hearts
I was anxious to find out if I could
seize some hemorrhage on those organs
I couldn't it wasn't epizootic
hemorrhagic disease with EHD ruled out
who or what is the killer
